Music again has demonstrated
its ability to soothe the savage
breast. For one evening at least
the sound of the banjo, the wail of
the saxophone, and the harmony
of male voices held sway in a hallusually devoted to the arts of war.
In other words, the Belair Arrnory was the scene of the (Musical Club's latest success of the
season, and the third annual success at Belair.
The concert given:last Friday
evening for the benefit of the Belair Athletic Association was up to
the best standards of the Club.
Unfortunately the piano solo had
to be cancelled on account of the
condition of ihe piano, -but with
this exception the program was
the same as it has been at preceding concerts. The numbers followed each other smoothly and
Were well received by the audience which numbered about four
hundred and fifty, a great many of
Whom accompanied the club from
Baltimore.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 10, 1925

ARE OUR SPORTING INTERESTS ASLEEP?
Without a swimming team, without a basketball. team, Johns
Hopkins is passing the winter months between foodtball and the lacrosse season devoid of athletic interests. Though events of'nonathletic importance spot the campus calendar, there is only one athletic contests to arouse the interest of the students. As a result, athletic enthusiasm has died down and perforce our sporting blood has
cooled to a degree of abnormality.
True, the lull during the "non-athletic" season is not of our own
choosing. If conditions, financial and otherwise, are such that minor
mid-winter sports must be dispensed with, we can only suffer the consequences. Still the fact remains, our athletic interests at the present
time are dormant.
The annual Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Indoor Games, the highwater mark of the Hopkins mid-winter season, are scheduled for
February 23. Never before in the history of indoor track has the
Baltimore public or Johns Hopkins had the opportunity of seeing
such a collection of world-famed stars, runners such as Nurmi, Ritola, Ray, Booth, Clark, Murchison and others. Other colleges and
sport fans are looking forward with interest to this athletic feature.
Many students elsewhere are known to be "hocking" their watches in
order to procure the necessary means to attend such a stellar meet.
Still the Hopkins campus continues to go on in the same smooth
easy going trend, with an air of indifference toward the indoor meet.
The question, are our sporting interests asleep, answers itself in the
affirmative.
Whatever the cause of this apparent lack of interest, whether or
not it is a result of the absence of minor sports, it is a condition which
should be curbed, lest the students sleep through the meet on February 23. Obviously, the solution of the problem should be left in
the hands of the Athletic Association. Perhaps that group could
awaken interest by bringing the importance of the meet to the students' attention at the weekly Assemblies. Perhaps a student section at the Armory might be reserved with tickets at a slightly reduced price. Any method of arousing interest will insure greater attendance and add to the success of the meet.

Following one of the longest
sieges of wintry weather that has
ever transformed this "Dixieland"
campus into that of a more northern clime, spring-like warmth,
borne on the crest of a gentle south
wind, served Thursday and Friday
to dissipate wintry omens and lend
a faint verdure to the ground so
long snow covered. It did more
than that, however. It permeated
the campus with an air of awakening, which was manifested in the
undergraduates, just emerging from
the inevitable stupor caused by unaccustomed concentration.
Out behind the engineering buildings a group of students engaged in
a baseball match, and down in front
of the Barn Store, such a display
of ties were arrayed that smoked
glasses, many of them bought for
the recent eclipse,, were suggested
as the only remedy from the dazzling colors exaggerated by the sunlight. In the rest room of the barn
a piano syncopated such strains as

only a hint of spring could inspire.
Weather in itself is interesting,
but of still more interest is the reaction of human beings to the
moods of the elements. This influence, which Shakespeare so loved
to dwell upon, is just as evident today as it ever was, and it is on a
college campus that this influence
is best perceived and appreciated.
Members of the faculty sitting
by open windows turn their attentions to poems and writings of the
azure skies and breezes gentle
ozones, written of every land in
the native tongue of each. Some
devote themselves to leisurely
thoughtful strolls along the boarded walks of the upper quadrangle
and the graveled paths of the botanical garden. Botanists reflect
on plant life and the coming
spring, Historians are thoughtful
over international problems, and
economists cogitate on new farm
problems. It is a pity we have no
Agricultural College to discuss
the planting of crops.

MISS BERGER POSTPONES
COACHING "FEMALES"

COTILLION CLUB DANCE
WELL ATTENDED

William Cooper, '25, Wins Poster Design Contest; Pictures
Postponed

Miss Hilda Bergner, Vagabond
player, who was to coach the female characters in the Barnstormers' forthcoming production, was
unable to attend their rehearsal
Sunday but will endeavor to assist
Coach Walter B. Swindell, Jr.,
next week.
Pictures of the leading characters who were to be photographed
Saturday morning were also postponed until a later date due to
Bachrach's inability to accommodate the Club on that date.
The competition for a poster design was won by William Cooper,
'25, and the cards are now being
printed.
Work on the forthcoming production, "The Tailor Made Man,"
has been progressing steadily and
rehearsals will be held Tuesday
and Thursday nights this week.
REPORTER AWAITS END OF THE
WORLD ON CAMPUS
Continued from page 1

the dark woods about the Botanical Gardens.
Eleven forty-five found the red
district lights still burning in the
new Chem Lab. The reporter noted
with a sigh the youth of this building so soon to be cut off.
The hour of the millenium approached. The reporter drew his
trusty pencil. His readers should
have a vivid picture of Homewood
in the act of disintegrating. Suddenly the clock in the tower of Gilman Hall began to boom twelve.
Nothing could have presaged the
millenium more clearly. For the
first time since 1916 the clock had
struck after six o'clock in the evening. Surely the end of the world
must be near. Eager, pencil in hand,
the news-gatherer waited. Minutes
slipped by, the millenium was late.
Perhaps it was not running on
Eastern Standard time. The reporter waited.
At 2 A. M. the moon still soared
serenely, the red lights gleamed, the
old clock slumbered soundly once
again, the merry students had disappeared, and the disappointed reporter slinked home. The gods do
not keep their engagements.

First Saturday Night Dance
Exams Brings Crowd

After

Capering to the strains of popular tunes rendered by "Jack"
Scherr and his Blue Jay Twin Six
a large crowd danced the evening
away in the C. E. Hall last Saturday night. It was the occasion of
one of the regular Cotillion Club
Saturday night dances and was
unusually well attended by the
undergraduates and their "fernmes."
Many preparatory school boys
were admitted under the recommendation of some undergraduates.
The Twin Six Orchestra was as
popular and "peppy" as usual and
were dressed in their tuxedoes,
decorated with a black and blue
ribbon across the shirt front, just
as they were at the last Cotillion.
The festivities were brought to
a close at midnight.

IF you are a good soldier, you take orders from
the major. But there is a great deal of difference whether you find the training an irksome
routine or an enjoyable development.
When you follow the right major in your course,
the work can become vitally interesting, and your
college career will be more worthwhile.
"But what is my right line of work?," may be
a puzzling question. All the thought you can give
to finding the answer will be fully repaid. Analyze
yourselfand you will surely discover your natural
aptitude.
And when you've found what line you feel you
ought to follow, stick to it. Stand by your major
and your major will stand by you.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-Lari ER, FEBRUARY 10, 1925
R. P. BIGELOW IN
FAVOR OF CHANGE
R. P. Bigelow, Ph. D., '92,
was among the more distant
voters in the NEWS-LETTER'S
recent canvass for the new
plan. Dr. Bigelow is at present at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but is
a regular subscriber to the
NEWS-LETTER.
Dr. Bigelow voted in favor
of the change in the undergraduate departments. "I think
this would help to restore the
University to its former position of leadership in higher
education," he wrote.

Urner and Rodgers Contribute Hits

Follows Performance

Music again has demonstrated
its ability to soothe the savage
breast. For one evening at least
the sound of the banjo, the wail of
the saxophone, and the harmony
of male voices held sway in a hallusually devoted to the arts of war.
In other words, the Belair Arrnory was the scene of the (Musical Club's latest success of the
season, and the third annual success at Belair.
The concert given:last Friday
evening for the benefit of the Belair Athletic Association was up to
the best standards of the Club.
Unfortunately the piano solo had
to be cancelled on account of the
condition of ihe piano, -but with
this exception the program was
the same as it has been at preceding concerts. The numbers followed each other smoothly and
Were well received by the audience which numbered about four
hundred and fifty, a great many of
Whom accompanied the club from
Baltimore.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 10, 1925

ARE OUR SPORTING INTERESTS ASLEEP?
Without a swimming team, without a basketball. team, Johns
Hopkins is passing the winter months between foodtball and the lacrosse season devoid of athletic interests. Though events of'nonathletic importance spot the campus calendar, there is only one athletic contests to arouse the interest of the students. As a result, athletic enthusiasm has died down and perforce our sporting blood has
cooled to a degree of abnormality.
True, the lull during the "non-athletic" season is not of our own
choosing. If conditions, financial and otherwise, are such that minor
mid-winter sports must be dispensed with, we can only suffer the consequences. Still the fact remains, our athletic interests at the present
time are dormant.
The annual Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Indoor Games, the highwater mark of the Hopkins mid-winter season, are scheduled for
February 23. Never before in the history of indoor track has the
Baltimore public or Johns Hopkins had the opportunity of seeing
such a collection of world-famed stars, runners such as Nurmi, Ritola, Ray, Booth, Clark, Murchison and others. Other colleges and
sport fans are looking forward with interest to this athletic feature.
Many students elsewhere are known to be "hocking" their watches in
order to procure the necessary means to attend such a stellar meet.
Still the Hopkins campus continues to go on in the same smooth
easy going trend, with an air of indifference toward the indoor meet.
The question, are our sporting interests asleep, answers itself in the
affirmative.
Whatever the cause of this apparent lack of interest, whether or
not it is a result of the absence of minor sports, it is a condition which
should be curbed, lest the students sleep through the meet on February 23. Obviously, the solution of the problem should be left in
the hands of the Athletic Association. Perhaps that group could
awaken interest by bringing the importance of the meet to the students' attention at the weekly Assemblies. Perhaps a student section at the Armory might be reserved with tickets at a slightly reduced price. Any method of arousing interest will insure greater attendance and add to the success of the meet.

Following one of the longest
sieges of wintry weather that has
ever transformed this "Dixieland"
campus into that of a more northern clime, spring-like warmth,
borne on the crest of a gentle south
wind, served Thursday and Friday
to dissipate wintry omens and lend
a faint verdure to the ground so
long snow covered. It did more
than that, however. It permeated
the campus with an air of awakening, which was manifested in the
undergraduates, just emerging from
the inevitable stupor caused by unaccustomed concentration.
Out behind the engineering buildings a group of students engaged in
a baseball match, and down in front
of the Barn Store, such a display
of ties were arrayed that smoked
glasses, many of them bought for
the recent eclipse,, were suggested
as the only remedy from the dazzling colors exaggerated by the sunlight. In the rest room of the barn
a piano syncopated such strains as

only a hint of spring could inspire.
Weather in itself is interesting,
but of still more interest is the reaction of human beings to the
moods of the elements. This influence, which Shakespeare so loved
to dwell upon, is just as evident today as it ever was, and it is on a
college campus that this influence
is best perceived and appreciated.
Members of the faculty sitting
by open windows turn their attentions to poems and writings of the
azure skies and breezes gentle
ozones, written of every land in
the native tongue of each. Some
devote themselves to leisurely
thoughtful strolls along the boarded walks of the upper quadrangle
and the graveled paths of the botanical garden. Botanists reflect
on plant life and the coming
spring, Historians are thoughtful
over international problems, and
economists cogitate on new farm
problems. It is a pity we have no
Agricultural College to discuss
the planting of crops.

MISS BERGER POSTPONES
COACHING "FEMALES"

COTILLION CLUB DANCE
WELL ATTENDED

William Cooper, '25, Wins Poster Design Contest; Pictures
Postponed

Miss Hilda Bergner, Vagabond
player, who was to coach the female characters in the Barnstormers' forthcoming production, was
unable to attend their rehearsal
Sunday but will endeavor to assist
Coach Walter B. Swindell, Jr.,
next week.
Pictures of the leading characters who were to be photographed
Saturday morning were also postponed until a later date due to
Bachrach's inability to accommodate the Club on that date.
The competition for a poster design was won by William Cooper,
'25, and the cards are now being
printed.
Work on the forthcoming production, "The Tailor Made Man,"
has been progressing steadily and
rehearsals will be held Tuesday
and Thursday nights this week.
REPORTER AWAITS END OF THE
WORLD ON CAMPUS
Continued from page 1

the dark woods about the Botanical Gardens.
Eleven forty-five found the red
district lights still burning in the
new Chem Lab. The reporter noted
with a sigh the youth of this building so soon to be cut off.
The hour of the millenium approached. The reporter drew his
trusty pencil. His readers should
have a vivid picture of Homewood
in the act of disintegrating. Suddenly the clock in the tower of Gilman Hall began to boom twelve.
Nothing could have presaged the
millenium more clearly. For the
first time since 1916 the clock had
struck after six o'clock in the evening. Surely the end of the world
must be near. Eager, pencil in hand,
the news-gatherer waited. Minutes
slipped by, the millenium was late.
Perhaps it was not running on
Eastern Standard time. The reporter waited.
At 2 A. M. the moon still soared
serenely, the red lights gleamed, the
old clock slumbered soundly once
again, the merry students had disappeared, and the disappointed reporter slinked home. The gods do
not keep their engagements.

First Saturday Night Dance
Exams Brings Crowd

After

Capering to the strains of popular tunes rendered by "Jack"
Scherr and his Blue Jay Twin Six
a large crowd danced the evening
away in the C. E. Hall last Saturday night. It was the occasion of
one of the regular Cotillion Club
Saturday night dances and was
unusually well attended by the
undergraduates and their "fernmes."
Many preparatory school boys
were admitted under the recommendation of some undergraduates.
The Twin Six Orchestra was as
popular and "peppy" as usual and
were dressed in their tuxedoes,
decorated with a black and blue
ribbon across the shirt front, just
as they were at the last Cotillion.
The festivities were brought to
a close at midnight.

IF you are a good soldier, you take orders from
the major. But there is a great deal of difference whether you find the training an irksome
routine or an enjoyable development.
When you follow the right major in your course,
the work can become vitally interesting, and your
college career will be more worthwhile.
"But what is my right line of work?," may be
a puzzling question. All the thought you can give
to finding the answer will be fully repaid. Analyze
yourselfand you will surely discover your natural
aptitude.
And when you've found what line you feel you
ought to follow, stick to it. Stand by your major
and your major will stand by you.

R. P. BIGELOW IN

R. P. Bigelow, Ph. D., '92,
was among the more distant
voters in the NEWS-LETTER'S
recent canvass for the new
plan. Dr. Bigelow is at present at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but is
a regular subscriber to the

Dr. Bigelow voted in favor
of the change in the undergraduate departments. "I think
this would help to restore the
University to its former position of leadership in higher
education," he wrote.
